questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 2.1, what does Srila Prabhupada say about Arjuna's compassion?
choices: Material compassion for the dress of a drowning man is senseless
Compassion means refusing to fight to avoid causing bodily harm
Any kind of compassion reflects true spiritual advancement regardless of object
Expressing compassion for family members shows proper understanding of relationships
questions.feedback: Correct: Srila Prabhupada explains that compassion for the eternal soul is self-realization, while compassion for the gross material body is senseless-like saving a drowning man by rescuing only his clothes. Arjuna's compassion targets the wrong object (relatives' bodies), producing confusion rather than clarity. Why this matters: Material sentimentality masquerades as transcendental mercy when we focus on the body's temporary distress while neglecting the soul's eternal welfare. Genuine mercy addresses the soul's bondage to the birth-death cycle, not bodily comfort. Discriminate between material emotion (attachment-based) and spiritual compassion (knowledge-based).

questions.prompt: In BG 2.2, what does Krishna say about Arjuna's impurities (kasmalam)?
choices: They are befitting a warrior overwhelmed by family love
They lead not to higher planets but to infamy
They demonstrate proper respect for elders and superiors
They show Arjuna's advanced understanding of compassionate principles
questions.feedback: Correct: Krishna criticizes Arjuna's lamentation as kasmalam (impurities) not befitting an Aryan-deviation from kshatriya duty leads not to higher planets but to infamy. Krishna's critique is surgical: impurities aren't sins requiring atonement but contaminations obscuring natural dharma-sense. Spiritual advancement sometimes appears harsh because sentiment masquerading as ethics must be exposed. Krishna's uncompromising response models the guru's role-removing illusion even when the disciple is attached to confusion.

questions.prompt: Why does Arjuna's respect for Bhisma and Drona create a moral dilemma in BG 2.4?
choices: They represent both his enemies and those worthy of worship
They are worthy of worship, so fighting them is never permissible
They are weaker than him but demand false respect
They have betrayed their duty as warriors in this conflict
questions.feedback: Correct: Bhisma and Drona stand as opponents yet remain worthy of worship (pujarhau)-creating a dharma-sankat (duty-dilemma) between prescribed duty and natural respect. Dharma sometimes requires opposing respected persons when they support adharma. Relationships and duty operate on different planes-one can honor someone as guru while opposing their current action. Personal affection cannot override transcendental obligation determined by shastra-vidhi.

questions.prompt: What attitude does Arjuna adopt in BG 2.7 toward Krsna?
choices: He asks Krsna for advice but keeps final decision
He surrenders as a disciple and asks for instruction
He seeks reassurance from Krsna without accepting discipline
He treats Krsna as equal friend not spiritual master
questions.feedback: Correct: Arjuna surrenders as sisya (disciple) requesting instruction, abandoning half-measures like seeking advice while retaining decision-control. He models complete shelter: 'I am Your disciple, soul surrendered unto You; please instruct me.' This represents a qualitative shift from friendship-based dialogue to guru-disciple relationship requiring submission. Without this surrender, Krishna's subsequent teachings would remain theoretical options rather than authoritative direction.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 2.11, what false path does Srila Prabhupada warn against regarding lamentation?
choices: That emotional expression for material loss demonstrates spiritual sensitivity and advancement
That the wise lament neither the living nor dead recognizing soul eternality
That grieving for the soul's temporary bondage shows proper spiritual understanding
That expressing compassion through lamentation indicates evolved consciousness and empathy
questions.feedback: Correct: Srila Prabhupada explains that lamentation for material bodies-living or dead-indicates ignorance of the soul's eternal nature (pandita sama-darshina). The wise neither lament the living nor the dead because they recognize the soul beyond bodily modifications. Why this matters: Mistaking material compassion for self-realization means grieving bodily changes while ignoring the soul's continuity. Material sentiment (attachment to bodies) differs categorically from spiritual wisdom (vision of soul). Test wisdom not by emotional depth but by transcendental discrimination.

questions.prompt: In BG 2.12, what does Krishna establish about individual existence?
choices: There was a time when we did not exist
Never was there a time when I did not exist
Individuality is temporary illusion that will end after liberation
All beings merge into one existence in the future
questions.feedback: Correct: Krishna declares 'na tv evaham jatu nasam'-never was there a time when I did not exist, nor you, nor these kings; nor shall any cease to be. The verse explicitly establishes eternal individuality: past, present, and future all include distinct persons. This refutes both Buddhist momentariness (we didn't exist before) and Mayavada merging (won't exist distinctly after). Personal eternal relationship with Krishna is sanatana-dharma's foundation-not achieving undifferentiated oneness but perfecting loving service to the eternally distinct Lord.

questions.prompt: How does BG 2.13 illustrate the soul's continuity through bodily changes?
choices: Like a river flowing continuously through different changing landscapes
As embodied soul passes from boyhood to youth to age
Like seasons changing from spring to summer to winter
As consciousness expands from childhood ignorance to mature wisdom
questions.feedback: Correct: The embodied soul (dehi) passes from kaumaram (boyhood) to yauvanam (youth) to jara (old age)-the same soul changing bodies. One continuous observer experiences bodily transformations without being transformed: 'I was a child, I am an adult, I will be old.' Tatha dehantara-praptih (similarly obtaining another body) extends this principle beyond one lifetime-death is just another transformation like puberty. Grief for death betrays the same ignorance as grief for aging-mistaking the body's changes for the self's changes.

questions.prompt: Why does BG 2.14 compare happiness and distress to summer and winter?
choices: To show they are unavoidable and must be accepted as destiny
Temporary sensations come and go like seasons; endure them
Happiness and distress alternate predictably like seasonal weather cycles
To demonstrate that both states are equally valuable for spiritual growth
questions.feedback: Correct: Happiness and distress are compared to sheeta-ushna (winter-summer)-temporary sense-contact sensations that are agamapayino'nitya (come-go, impermanent), requiring titiksha (tolerance). The seasonal analogy reveals dualities' inherent impermanence: winter inevitably becomes summer becomes winter. Recognizing this temporary nature removes their power to disturb-tolerance flows from understanding, not willpower. Spiritual equanimity requires grasping material existence's oscillatory nature, not developing emotional numbness.

questions.prompt: According to BG 2.15, who is eligible for liberation?
choices: One disturbed by happiness and distress in daily life's situations
One steady and not disturbed by happiness or distress
One who accumulates wealth through honest work and material endeavors
One who renounces without understanding the goal of life
questions.feedback: Correct: One who is sama-duhkha-sukham (steady amid distress-happiness) qualifies for amrtatvaya (immortality/liberation). Eligibility is determined not by situation but by consciousness-the ability to remain undisturbed regardless of externals. Liberation doesn't come after achieving comfort but through equanimity amid discomfort. The dhira (sober person) possesses this steadiness now, not after material problems are solved.

questions.prompt: How does the distinction in BG 2.16 between the nonexistent and the eternal resolve Arjuna's grief?
choices: Both body and soul eventually merge into one undifferentiated spiritual existence
Since the body is temporary and soul eternal, death changes nothing real
All individual distinctions between souls and bodies are ultimately false conceptions
Neither the soul nor the body can be known with any real certainty
questions.feedback: Correct: The verse distinguishes asat (nonexistent body) from sat (existent soul)-asat na vidyate bhava (nonexistent has no endurance), sat na vidyate abhava (existent has no cessation). Why this matters: Treating body and soul as equally real but different misses the categorical distinction between temporary and eternal. The body participates in nonexistence throughout, being perpetually changing; the soul participates in eternality throughout. This resolves Arjuna's grief by exposing a category error: lamenting change in what's inherently changeable while ignoring the unchanging observer.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 2.20, what does Srila Prabhupada explain as the symptom of the soul's presence?
choices: The warmth and life energy circulating through the body
Consciousness spread throughout the body like sunlight from the sun
The breath moving in and out indicating vitality
The ability to think and reason distinguishing humans from animals
questions.feedback: Correct: Consciousness is a symptom of the soul-like sunlight indicates the sun's presence even when clouds hide it, consciousness indicates the soul's presence in the body. Srila Prabhupada establishes consciousness as lakshana (symptom) not product: an effect indicating a cause without being reducible to that cause. Where consciousness exists, the soul is present; where no consciousness, the soul is absent. This provides empirical verification of the soul's presence through its symptomatic effect.

questions.prompt: How does the garment analogy in BG 2.22 refute the fear of death?
choices: Death brings complete annihilation of existence and identity
It shows the soul remains unchanged while bodies are exchanged
Individual identity ceases when the soul merges into the supreme
Consciousness ceases when the body dies since both are interdependent
questions.feedback: Correct: The soul changing bodies is compared to a person changing clothes-vasamsi jirnani (worn garments) are discarded for navani (new ones). Just as no one grieves discarding old clothes for new, one shouldn't grieve discarding an old body for a new one. Death isn't the self's termination but the self's relocation. Transcend bodily identification by recognizing the self as eternal inhabitant, not temporary dwelling-this transforms death from tragedy to transition.

questions.prompt: Why does BG 2.25 emphasize the soul as invisible, inconceivable and immutable?
choices: Only what can be measured and perceived exists in reality
To show the soul transcends material perception and speculation
The soul is merely a temporary combination of material elements
What cannot be seen or touched must not truly exist
questions.feedback: Correct: The soul is described as avyakta (invisible), acintya (inconceivable), and avikary (immutable)-transcending material perception and speculation categories. The soul's transcendental nature means it escapes material detection methods by definition: invisibility indicates spiritual substance, inconceivability shows it's beyond mental categories, immutability establishes unchanging reality beneath changing phenomena. These qualities render grief philosophically invalid-if the soul transcends material perception, bodily death (a material event) cannot affect it. Spiritual realization requires transcending empiricist assumptions and accepting reality beyond sense-perception through shabda-pramana.

questions.prompt: In BG 2.30, why need one not grieve for any living being?
choices: Because grieving shows devotion and humility toward those who leave
Because he who dwells in the body can not be slain
Because the soul will be reborn anyway, so grief is unnecessary
Because suffering is only imagination, so grief is pointless
questions.feedback: Correct: The verse states that the dehi (indwelling self) na hanyate (cannot be slain)-removing lamentation's basis absolutely. Grief is unnecessary not because rebirth compensates for death but because death cannot touch the soul's essential nature-this is an ontological impossibility, not cyclical consolation. Killing the body doesn't injure the soul any more than destroying a car injures the driver. Soul-indestructibility dissolves grief completely, while rebirth-logic (still a material framework) merely postpones it.

questions.prompt: According to BG 2.47, what is the proper relationship between work and its results?
choices: One has right to fruits if work is done properly
One has right to perform duty but not to fruits
One should avoid work entirely to prevent attachment to results
One should work only when results are guaranteed to be favorable
questions.feedback: Correct: The verse establishes adhikara (right) to karmani (prescribed work) but not to phaleshu (fruits)-a revolutionary principle separating action from result. Why this matters: Results-driven action means performing duty contingent on guaranteed outcomes, producing anxiety and attachment. Right to action exists unconditionally; right to results doesn't exist at all-results belong to Krishna's arrangement, not our control. This frees us from dual bondage: attachment to performing (when success is expected) and attachment to not-performing (when failure is feared). Perform duty as offering regardless of result, transforming work from selfish transaction to selfless service.

questions.prompt: In BG 2.49, how does Krishna characterize work done for fruitive results compared to buddhi-yoga?
choices: Fruitive work can be offered to Krishna later for purification
Abominable activities should be kept far distant by devotional service
Planning one's work intelligently demonstrates buddhi-yoga in practice
Desiring fruits from work is natural and spiritually neutral
questions.feedback: Correct: Krishna calls fruitive work avaram karma (abominable activity) to be kept durena (far distant) through buddhi-yoga-extraordinarily strong language. Fruit-seeking isn't spiritually neutral but spiritually poisonous-it creates karpanya (miserliness), treating Krishna's energy as a personal resource for exploitation. Buddhi-yoga (devotional service) represents a qualitative alternative, not quantitative refinement-a different orientation entirely, not just less intensity. Don't moderate material consciousness-transcend it through devotional engagement.

questions.prompt: According to BG 2.55, what characterizes one in pure transcendental consciousness (sthita-prajna)?
choices: One who moderates all sense desires through strict disciplined regulation
One who gives up all sense desires, satisfied in the self alone
One who fulfills all desires systematically to achieve final detachment
One who analyzes desires philosophically before acting on them selectively
questions.feedback: Correct: The sthita-prajna abandons sarva-kaman (all desires) for sense gratification, satisfied atmani eva atmana (in self alone by self). The sthita-prajna doesn't suppress desires but transcends them-satisfaction shifts from external objects to internal realization. In Krishna consciousness, desires subside automatically without extraneous effort-higher taste dissolves lower attachment. Don't fight desires directly-cultivate superior satisfaction, allowing lower desires to wither from disinterest.

questions.prompt: How do the arguments about the soul's eternality (BG 2.12-25) and Arjuna's warrior duty (BG 2.31-32) work together to resolve his crisis?
choices: Both reveal duty transcends personal comfort; act despite difficulty
Eternal soul makes death illusory; kshatriya duty makes fighting righteous
They contradict each other revealing inconsistency in teaching
Either fighting or fleeing would be acceptable since all choices are relative
questions.feedback: Correct: Krishna synthesizes metaphysics (2.12-25 soul eternality) with ethics (2.31-32 kshatriya duty)-a two-pronged resolution of Arjuna's crisis. The soul's indestructibility removes the philosophical objection (can't truly kill anyone), while kshatriya-dharma provides positive justification (righteous war for righteous warrior). Together they eliminate paralysis: Arjuna no longer fears action's consequences (metaphysical security) while having clear direction to act (ethical imperative). Spiritual discrimination requires an integrated approach-transcendental philosophy grounding material duty, producing fearless righteous action.

questions.prompt: How does Prabhupada's teaching on tolerating dualities (BG 2.14-15) inform the instruction to perform duty with equanimity (BG 2.48)?
choices: Forcefully suppressing all emotional reactions creates true spiritual detachment
Recognizing impermanence of sense experience enables balanced action in duties
Work outcomes are predetermined by fate so they don't actually matter
Experiencing material pleasures helps one advance spiritually through gradual satisfaction
questions.feedback: Correct: The teaching connects dualities' impermanence (2.14-15 winter-summer) with yoga-stha (2.48 equipoised action)-metaphysical insight enabling practical equanimity. Recognizing dualities' inherent temporality (agamapayino'nitya) removes their power to disturb-consciousness is freed through understanding, not suppression. Equanimity flows from insight, not effort-seeing the winter-summer pattern makes their alternation non-threatening. Tolerance arises automatically from correctly understanding material nature, not from forcing emotional neutrality.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 2.7, what false path does Srila Prabhupada warn against regarding family attachment?
choices: Families naturally protect each other from death eternally
Family attachment is based on 'skin disease' mentality
Only humans can be affectionate to relatives and family
Society can definitely save one from death through collective effort
questions.feedback: Correct: Srila Prabhupada calls family attachment 'skin disease'-superficial bodily identification. The krpana (miser) thinks family can protect from death. Why this matters: Sentimentalized domesticity treats family relationships as spiritually ultimate, providing existential security and permanent satisfaction, but family affection based on shared 'skin' represents material consciousness masquerading as love. Family cannot protect from death because death is the body's destiny, not the soul's problem. Maintain family responsibilities while recognizing only Krishna provides actual protection-family as service-field, not security-source.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 2.7, who does Srila Prabhupada describe as a miserly person (krpana)?
choices: One who hoards wealth through legitimate means and proper work
One who solves life's problems as a human should
One who quits without understanding self-realization like cats and dogs
One who becomes detached from family life and material affairs
questions.feedback: Correct: The krpana (miser) quits life without solving the human form's purpose-like cats and dogs dying without self-realization. Why this matters: Wasting human opportunity means living for eating, sleeping, mating, and defending like animals, failing to address atma-jnana (self-knowledge) unique to the human platform. Human life's value lies in the potential for self-realization-squandering this through material pursuit alone constitutes ultimate miserliness. Cats and dogs cannot inquire about transcendence; humans who don't are voluntarily reducing themselves to animal consciousness. Prioritize atma-tattva inquiry-temporary comfort is available in any species, spiritual liberation only in human form.

questions.prompt: According to BG 2.17, what is the indestructible principle that pervades the entire body?
choices: The spirit soul (atma), which cannot be destroyed
The body's vital air (prana) circulating through organs and limbs
The blood flowing from the heart to all body parts
The mind and intelligence expanding through the nervous system
questions.feedback: Correct: The verse identifies the avinashi (imperishable) principle pervading the body-the soul, whose presence is known through the symptom of consciousness. The soul transcends all biological functions: prana circulates because the soul is present, not vice versa. Consciousness indicates the soul like temperature indicates fire-a symptomatic effect proving an immaterial cause. Where consciousness exists, the soul is present; where no consciousness, the soul has departed.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 2.13, why does Srila Prabhupada say the Mayavadi theory of oneness cannot be entertained?
choices: Because individuality is only a temporary illusion during material existence
Because cutting the Supreme into fragmental souls would make Him changeable
Because oneness philosophy contradicts the need for spiritual teachers
Because the soul's eternal nature prevents any philosophical speculation
questions.feedback: Correct: Srila Prabhupada refutes the Mayavada 'cutting' theory-if souls were cut from the Supreme, He would become changeable, contradicting His immutability. Fragmental portions (vibhinnamshas) exist eternally as individuals-not produced by division but constitutionally distinct. The Supreme remains unchanged while souls remain eternal-both immutable but in different categories (infinite vs infinitesimal). Acintya-bhedabheda (inconceivable oneness-difference) resolves what emanation cannot: simultaneous relationship and distinction without compromising either party's nature.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 2.13, why does Srila Prabhupada say the instructor-instructed relationship between Krsna and Arjuna is meaningful?
choices: Both are on the same level of realization and spiritual understanding
Both are equally deluded by maya's influence and material energy
Krsna is superior, Arjuna is forgetful soul deluded by maya
Arjuna is the Supreme teaching the subordinate Krsna divine knowledge
questions.feedback: Correct: The Krishna-Arjuna instructor-instructed relationship is meaningful because Krishna is Supreme while Arjuna is bhramita (forgetful soul deluded by maya). The relationship isn't expert teaching novice (quantitative difference) but Supreme instructing conditioned (qualitative difference). Krishna's superiority is constitutional, not circumstantial-never deluded, eternally conscious; Arjuna's inferiority is present condition, not permanent nature-forgetful but recoverable. This establishes the teaching's possibility: the Supreme can enlighten the conditioned through knowledge-transmission.

questions.prompt: How does Prabhupada's teaching that the body is like clothes (BG 2.22) integrate with Krishna's instruction to fight without attachment to results (BG 2.38, 2.47)?
choices: Soul and bodily action operate in completely separate realms with no connection
Soul-body distinction enables duty performance without existential investment in outcomes
Understanding the soul's nature means one should avoid all material responsibilities
True detachment requires mechanically suppressing all natural emotions during action
questions.feedback: Correct: The teaching integrates the body-as-clothes metaphor (2.22) with detached duty-performance (2.38, 2.47)-philosophical foundation enabling practical application. Soul-body distinction enables duty performance without existential investment: if bodies are mere garments, bodily outcomes (victory/defeat) don't affect the essential self. Perform kshatriya duty appropriate for the current body without confusion that results touch the soul. Metaphysical knowledge serves a practical purpose-transforming action from self-interested grasping to self-aware offering.
